I dare not look upon the giving of it.

sp.p: If that be all, the sight of it shall never trouble you-oh. they sink.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Ha, ha, ha. You have made my conscience whole
Again with laughing. Why took ye not your money with ye to
Drink among the furies? Ha, ha, ha. D'ye hear my friends?
Pray stay, take your money; are you so
Quickly out of hearing? What shallow rogues were
These till now? now they are deep enough, men of
Profound understanding; this gimcrack I devised for
Their entertainment; where you shall fast and welcome
Gentlemen, till you have tried the conclusion, whether famine
Can break stone walls; I am sure they are thick enough
To drown your cries, though they be louder than the
Voice of vengeance. So ends their scene. Some conscience now
Would ask me, why hast thou
Dispatched thy father and thy brother thus?
But mine informs me, I did very well.
Your reason sir, replies the scrupulous conscience?
Mine roundly answers that my brother was
Elder than I, and by right to inherit
My father's fair possessions, of which
I have so sweetly tasted. But your father
By a most dear and supernatural love
Gave you the greater blessing; and in time
Might have conferred all on you by your policy.
To this again I answer, that my father,
Whose dotage merely and not my deserts
Made him so good to me, might in my absence
Have idly grown as fond on tother side.
For to speak truth, and not to wrong the dead,
My brother was religious, pious, honest ▪
And was endued with all these unknown gifts
Which holy men call virtues; which in the end
If they be suffered to run on will find
Double reward, they say. His could not be
Found here, but in my loss, and by my father.
Now if they may be had ith' tother world,
I am so far from being their hindrance,
That I have sent them both the nighest way.
Many good reasons more I could deliver,
But that I am prevented.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Ods my pity,
Be comforted good madam, can you think
By casting down yourself to raise them up
From death again? what? you have yet a brother
May stead you for a father, husband,
Friend, or what you will.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.p: I have a mind to watch you though a little.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: You've heard the news, and mourn for't I perceive,
Of the unfortunate ends of our dear father,
And our beloved brother.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.p: E'en drowned in grief too brother.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Troth I was
Sunk over head and ears; but am wept out
Of sorrows lake e'en dropping dry, as they say;
And have done what I can to shake it off.
And would now counsel thee, my beauteous sister,
To clear those looks again, that only can
Revive my drooping heart, we only are
Left now to be each others comforter.
I have made known my love to you.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: O my brother,
That knowledge is a grief of no less horror,
Then was the bloody news that pierced my heart.
Mention that love no more, nor call it love,
Which is but foul desire.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Peace, hear but this,
D'ye think it is not love? would I desire
You in that nearest kind, if I not loved you?

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.p: What? love a sister so? are you a man?

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.p: Sure I do hope so, and that you shall find it.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: Can you unto your shame seek my dishonour?
To damn us both, in that abhorred way
Which by avoiding, man is best distinguished
From the most brutish beasts.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: I cannot, may not peace, nor suffer word
Importing such a purpose pierce mine ears.
Twice have I beaten back your monstrous lust,
(Could I but call it lust, it were too much
Though in a monarch to my virgin honour;
But in you beastly incest) and before
I'll live in danger of one offer more,
I'll die by mine own hand.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: You shall not rob
Me so of my revenge, if you deny me.
And 'tis another argument of my love,
If't please you to collect it, that you have lived
Till now, still obstinate. But be you warned
And take withal to your consideration
Your provident father, and your valiant brother,
(Whom you so prized above me) are not now
To oversee or side you.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: He indeed
Was a most virtuous brother.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Therefore take
This for your latest warning;
This night to meet me in my full desires,
In your as free embraces, or pale death.
Go clear your eyes, and think on't; but be sure
You think to do withal as I command you.
I'll pitch thee headlong into hell else. Come,
I know thou wilt affect me; can there be
A nearer or more requisite love indeed
Then the sweet mixture of a brother and sister?
Well said, there was a blushing smile, that gave me
Thy full consent; oh thou wilt ravish me.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.p: Pray, let me think a little.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: Has taught me to dissemble; heaven that knows
My thoughts are chaste and pure, will pardon me
I hope, if to preserve my life and him
From greater sin, I use a little of
The art too too much practised among women,
Of smooth hypocrisy. I know his heart is bloody;
And he may be too sudden, if I win not
Time on him, by some subtler shift to wave
His foul attempts, until I get free
Out of this gripe to use my liberty.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: That I love
Your noble person, nay am taken with it,
With more than sisterly affection, is
A truth no way to be dissembled; you
Already like a well read scholar find it,
In Cupid's love-letters my friend, my maiden blushes.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: But when I consider,
What scandal, or what too near affinity
In noble blood, and the nobility of our house,
(Unfit to fall within the centre of the law,
Or the constructions of men's ruder manners)
May cast upon us.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Stay my lovely Mildred;
What? or whose eye, or thought, shall glance at us?
Whilst we in safest privacy enjoy
The bliss of mutual pleasure.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: It is yet
Too intricate a doubt for me to find
A resolution in. But my sweet lord,
(O that I could not call you brother) then
I would be nearer to you then a sister.
So eager and so equal is my love
With yours; if you please but to give me time,
But one weeks liberty, to frame myself
Obedient to your will in all, I now
Will give you a faithful pledge to render
The satisfaction you demand.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: You could not name a better,
Short of the further happiness I covet.
Give me't.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: But you shall swear by't that you will not
A bridge my liberty, nor urge your suit
Further these seven days.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: My patience never bought a kiss so dear.
But keep your vow.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.p: Well, well, I'll do my best.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: He's not yet perfect, you must strive my love,
To curb your hot desires, as I do mine.
I could myself dwell ever on your lips,
Never outgo the circle of your arms.
Could I but hope to be your wife. But oh,
What I have promised you, I must allow
At the time limited; till then urge it not.
For take my vow with yours, if you dare break it,
I dare to kill myself; and by that time,
If I not yield myself unto your will,
My life is yours either to save or kill.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.p: Go, thou'rt a noble wench, enjoy thy liberty.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: I have enough, listening is good sometimes.
Good heaven! who would have thought it? stay,
Let me not be too hasty.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Yet I fear,
I shall hardly hold out a week;
'Tis a great while believe't in such a case
As this, for one to forbear his own sister,
That has so good a mind to't. And perhaps
This may be cunning in her to delude me.
Were not I better take her by surprise,
In a soft sleep tonight ? sure I shall keep her
From killing of herself, till I be satisfied.
And then if she be weary of her life,
I may be kind enough to help her out on't;
Because she says she loves me. Out you beldame,
How in the name of Lucifer cam'st thou hither?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: O my good lord, I do beseech your honour,
Forbear your fury; I have such a business.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: To eavesdrop have you not? I am not safe,
Unless I kill this witch.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: My lord, my lord,
You are the lord that I do look to live by.
And if I die my lord, you lose the knowledge
Of such a secret.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: You will repent in hell my lord, if you or I
Should leave the world before you know the thing
That I can open to you; which when I have unfolded,
Kill me if you please. I did but watch occasion
To find you private to reveal it to you.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Thus it is my lord,
My lord, your father's dead.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.p: But are you sure they're dead?

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: I fear this jade
Has overheard me.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: For d'ye see my lord,
I would not in their life time have disclosed
This hidden matter for a whole world's good.
And thus it is, your father and your brother
Being dead, heaven rest their souls.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Nothing my lord, but now comes that concerns you;
Your father and your brother being gone,
(Heaven rest their souls) there I begin.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: You began there before, if that be the beginning,
your for ever world without end
We shall never come at it.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Now that concerns you;
You think you have a sister.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.p: No truly my good lord, you do but think so.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Is Mildred dead? has she destroyed herself?
Now since she left me here, to spite my love.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: You hear me not say so, I saw her not
Since I left both of you together here.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Unfold your riddle Sphinx, I'll dig it else
Out of your rotten belly. What's your meaning?

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Because she is unnatural; didst thou but know
What a poor easy request she denied me
Thou wouldst say she were unnatural indeed.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: I mean, she was not born of the same mother,
Nor got by the same father that you were.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.p: Speak that again; make but that good, I'll saint thee.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: My lord, I can and will maintain it, ay,
Not only for some wrong she did me lately,
Nor for the good my lord that you may do me,
Though all the estates your own when she's discarded;
But to let truth appear, which has been long
A burden, and an heavy burden, though I say't;
And so will any woman say, 'tis to keep council
So many years together as I have done,
I had much ado to keep it in, I wis,
In my good old lords days. Lord how he loved her!
But few men know their children, that's the truth on't;
And let that go.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: The point is this, I loved my old lord well;
Therefore was loath to grieve him; and I loved
My good old lady better; therefore I kept
Her council to this hour: you now are all
That's left of 'em; and whom should I love now
But your sweet self my lord? I'll tell you all:
This Mildred, whom you so long called sister,
Was not your fathers, nor your mother's child;
But in the absence of your father, when
Sixteen years since he was sent by the King
Upon an embassy, your mother then with child,
By sad mischance brought forth a still born babe;
At the same time a lady nobly born
Whose husband was in exile, brought forth this,
This lady Mildred.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Yes, and by woman's slight, of which this is
Not first example, th' infants were exchanged;
Because your loving father might find joy
In a fair daughter at his home-return.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: If in three days I do not
Make it appear most plain to you, multiply
Your wrath upon me.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Do so; and dost hear?
I'll never call old woman witch hereafter
Whate'er I think. We may be married now,
And Mildred's love may freely answer mine.
We now may safely mix, and to't again,
Strange strong events are labouring in my brain.
Come you with me.

sp.speaker: Eth.
sp.l: What fury has possessed 'em? all our art,
And the King's policy will be prevented,
By the brain-giddiness of these wilful lords.

sp.speaker: Edel.
sp.l: We have no way my lord, but to give way
Unto their violent rage, and quit the court.

sp.speaker: Eth.
sp.l: And since we can make good our place no longer,
Post after our King master, and leave them
with their new King at home here, that's as mad
As they.

sp.speaker: Edel.
sp.l: And madder too; I cannot wonder
More what he is, then at the fate that sent him.

div.stage: Enter Theodwald, eausride, guard, physician, 2. Attendants.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: My lord, both in the King and state's behalf,
In which you may excuse us.

sp.speaker: Eauf.
sp.l: Sh't, sh't, let ▪ him take it
How he or will or dare, we have agreed.
The body of the council have decreed it
You must depart the court.

sp.speaker: Eauf.
sp.l: Must and shall,
You and your trim confederate; you have had
The rule here over your ruler, till you have made him
Wild, frantic, mad, and us too; God forgive me
For saying so, almost as mad as he;
I hope it is no treason.

sp.speaker: Edel.
sp.l: No, cause you said almost;
But had you said you had been full as mad,
You had passed a subject's boldness.

sp.speaker: Eauf.
sp.l: Take 'em hence;
Thrust 'em out oth' court.

sp.speaker: Eth.
sp.l: Well my lord, when we see the King in's wits,
We'll tell him of our usage, that he may thank you.

sp.speaker: Eauf.
sp.l: In the mean time go travel on adventures,
Whilst we do our endeavour to amend
What you have marred by screwing the King's brain
Into the nick of order once again. Put forth a bed, Anthynus on it bound
See, see, my lord, how they have kept him dark,
Manacled and bound on's bed? was ever King
Used thus? for pity's sake unbind him quickly.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.p: What fiends or fairies are ye?

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.l: Let his passion
A little vent itself, ere you unbind him.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: What? new tormentors? or into what way
Of further mischief do ye mean to throw me?

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.p: We come to bring your highness' comfort.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Highness?
Have you that mockery for me too? I told
The rest that slaved me with that attribute,
From whence I came, who, what I was, and all
The story of my father's wrongs, and mine
(Too many ever to have been, but heaven
Marked 'em out for us) and I told 'em too
What I had undertaken by watching, fasting,
Prayers too (Unfit to boast of) with the industry
I practised to have found my wounded father.
For which (As though I durst have faith in merits)
They mocked me with the title of a King,
And bound me here as they thought to believe it.
'Tis a new way of punishment; and were due
To one that thought his duty meritorious.
But I will break these gives, and with my teeth
Tear off these manacles.

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.p: O do not strive my liege.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Thy liege, dog-leech? are you at that garb too?
I wish I had one finger loose to fillip out
Thy brains and skill together for the ratcatchers.

sp.speaker: Phys
sp.p: He thinks my skull's made but of urinal metal.

sp.speaker: Eauf
sp.p: Have but a little patience, we'll unloose you.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: A grave persuasion to a man that's tied to't.
Humh, humh, humh.

sp.speaker: Eauf.
sp.l: Beshrew their herds that used him thus to vex him.
How do you like him doctor?

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: Did you mark
His talk of wrongs, and of a wounded father?
And how he will not hear of being a King?

sp.speaker: Physician
sp.l: Ay, all, all, I know all; such fancies fall
Naturally into this disease, which now
is almost a wild frenzy, that will seldom
Suffer the patient think himself to be
The person that he is; nor oftentimes the creature,
But some fourfooted beast, or feathered fowl:
But could I fasten but a slumber on him,
Which must be the first entrance to my work.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Have you concluded yet your barbarous council?
If not, take my advice with ye: call the King,
The King with whose authority you scorn me;
Let him but hear (For you will never tell him)
From my own lips how willingly I'll give
My voice unto his marriage; and I'm sure
He'll set me free; at least by death.

sp.speaker: Eauf.
sp.l: Alas,
What King? what freedom would you have?
You are our King, and shall command your freedom,
And all our lives, would you but sleep a while.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Sleep? make no doubt of that; look, I can sleep,
With as much ease as one bound in a cart,
Driving to execution. But do you hear?
My vow was not to sleep nor eat until
I had performed a work, which I shall never,
Never accomplish, now my vow is broken.
For they by witchcraft charmed me into sleep,
And tempted me with meat at unawares,
Before my sleep-drowned senses were collected;
And put me on these unknown garments here,
With an hail master; so betrayed me into
This irksome folly, or this foolish thraldom.

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: 'Twas a rash vow, and so well broke; you now
Shall be released: unbind him at my peril.
These rigorous courses have done hurt upon him;
We have provided otherwise to please you;
For we have called Theodrick home again
Your favourite, whose absence was a grief to you;
Nay more, because 'tis thought your languishing love
Bred your distemper, we have taken care
For hastening of your marriage; your fair Queen
Is sent for, and at hand to ease your sorrow.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: My favourite, and my Queen! leave these abuses;
My hands and feet are now at liberty

sp.speaker: Theod.
sp.l: So is our duty, and if your majesty
Will tread cur due allegiance into dust,
We are prepared to suffer.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Would to heaven,
I could unfold this mystery.

sp.speaker: Eauf.
sp.l: See my lord,
Theodrick is come.

sp.speaker: Theodr.
sp.l: Most gracious sir,
That I have suffered under your displeasure,
In being barred your presence, which no less
Than the all cheering sun gave life to me,
Was not so much my grief, as not to know
What my transgression was; and let me now
Implore your mercy so far as to name it;
Which if I cannot clear me of, I'll lose my life, and willingly.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: If I could think this serious, 'twere enough
Almost to turn my sorrows into laughter.

sp.speaker: Theodr.
sp.l: O turn not from me royal sir, to augment
Your highness displeasure; but in case you will not
Be pleased to name my trespass, give me leave
To speak what I suppose has troubled you,
And caused me causelessly to be suspended.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: I feel a secret instigation in me,
I hope by some good angel that inclines me,
At last to yield a little to these men.
What wouldst thou say?

sp.speaker: Theodr.
sp.l: My lords, and all forbear
The presence; never fear, all shall be well.

sp.speaker: Eauf.
sp.l: Was not this my policy,
To send for him? more, was it not my wit
To fashion letters as with's own hand
to fetch the Queen? you'll see more at her coming.

sp.speaker: Theodr.
sp.p: May't please you now but to review these pictures.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Good memory help me; this is of the Queen,
The cruel Queen that banished my good father;
And this the lively image of my sister.

sp.speaker: Theodr.
sp.l: Now may it please your grace to recollect,
How when I told you this was my fair mistress,
Your passion first seized on you; and pardon royal sir,
If I have since conjectured my transgression
Was merely this, that I loved one so fair,
I dare not yet say fairer than your choice.
But freely thus, to expiate my trespass,
As I resign the picture, I give up
All interest in her person, never more
Beyond your free consent to see that beauty.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: I have found all the error, and am taught
By hidden inspiration to make use on't. Genius still whispers him.
Give me fresh raiment, I'll take all upon me
(Their crown if they will give it) yet methinks
This is so like a dream — where else can be
King Osrick all this while, that he comes not
To throw me out of this usurped right?
Strange and new thoughts possess me. Gen. whispers
Now I call
To mind the vision that I had of being
Called to the throne of the West Saxons Kings.
It must be by this Queen, whom how to love
I cannot find. My genius prompts me, yes
I hear it now, as by an angel spoke.
And that my vow was rashly made, well broken;
I am confirmed, and come she I am for her.Puts on hat, feather, and cloak) ex. Genius.
Well said Theodrick; (Theodrick is his name?)
How do I look Theodrick?

sp.speaker: Theodr.
sp.l: I can find
But little change, which I allow to sickness.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.l: News, neam King, news, news;
News that will make thee well, beest thou never so sick.
News that beest thou never so well, will make thee sick.
News that will make thee mad, beest thou never so tame.
News that beest thou never so mad, will make thee tame.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.l: A wife, a wife, a wife can do all this.
The Queen is come, and all my cousin lords
Are gone to fetch her in in pomp: o ho,
Knight me, o knight me quickly for my news.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.l: Away you favourite.
Hinder me not unless I prophesy,
Kings, fools and favourites never shall agree.
And many years after we are in our graves,
Fools shall be knights, and favourites shall be — known
From black sheep, I prophesy.
O ho, she comes, she comes; now neam King,
Bear up stiff before and meet her. Here's a day,
And a night towards indeed. O ho, the house
Begins to reel already, and all our brains turn
Round; o ho.

div.stage: Enter ushers bare, kelrick and Elkwin, Theodwald and Eaufride, a Cardinal, the Queen, two ladies bearing up her train, followers, the Queen Bertha kneels, Anthynus as King takes her up; kisses her; they confer, the four lords salute and confer; Theodwald and Eaufride give their supposed Kings hand to the Cardinal. Kelrick and Elkwin give their Queen's hand to the Cardinal; the Cardinal joins their hands, Anthynus and Bertha kiss; all the lords embrace; the exeunt in state as before.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.l: O what a night will here be? what a night will here be?
What a beast am I? that I have not at least half (Lasses with child now,
A score of my wholesome country
That forty weeks hence the Queen might have her
Choice of nurses; there had been a thriving way to raise
My fortunes indeed. O what a night will here be!

div.head: Act. v.
Scen. i.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Your cries will be in vain.
'Tis not in the power of any flesh but yours,
To allay, or to prevent my heat of blood.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: O you diviner powers that ordained chastity
To be a virtue, lend your strength to guard it.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Thy cries shall be as fruitless as thy life
If thou offendest me with 'em; hear but this
Impertinently peevish maid, and tremble
But to conceive a disobedient thought
Against my will. Canst thou without my favour,
Be better than a beggar?

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: Yet a beggar
Is better than a whore.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: How canst thou judge
That knowest not what is either? let a wench
That knows what's what, or has been both, maintain it;
But this is from the purpose; I am so far
From casting of thee off to be a beggar,
As I intend to make thee my rich equal,
And not a whore, but wife; you know your nurse
Has undertaken to find it lawful for us
To marry; and canst thou with modesty
Deny me present pleasure, that within these three days
Shall confer honour on thee for thy life?

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.p: Would you first spoil my honour to repair it?

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: Not before
Our covenant is passed; that is, the priest
Has joined our hearts and hands.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: By this account,
A man backs not his horse before he's paid for't;
Nor puts his nose into a house before
He buys the lease on't; leave your precise folly,
Madam formality; force me not to force thee,
Yield with that very breath thou now drawest in,
Or it returns thy last.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.p: This witch or devil haunts me.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: O my lord,
I told you late a wonder; I bring now
A miracle, a miracle.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Your brother is survived from death again;
My lord Anthynus is come home and safe ▪
The heavens be praised.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.p: O grant that it be true.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Nay, run me in as far as you can if I lie;
Up to the hilts if I lie.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.p: What canst thou mean by this?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Nay, what he means I knew not, for he denies his name,
Says he is not Anthynus, but a Northumbrian gentleman;
And desires conference with my lady Mildred
From the fine lord was here (What call you him?)
The Kings great favourite; but if I am I,
If you are you, if any thing be any thing,
It is Anthynus.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Go you to your chamber,
And be not seen I charge you. Let him enter,
But first send in my servants.
I did mistrust he lived; oh those false villains,
That faced me down they killed him, may they be
A year a famishing. Have you tricks Anthynus?
How can he think, though he disguised his name
Or country, that we should not know his person?
What should his aim or drift be? stay, perhaps
He does suspect I was in the action
against my father's life and his, and thinks him dead,
So steals upon me thus as his own ghost,
To terrify my conscience, shallow, shallow;
But I'll so fit him; it is most evidently he.

div.stage: Enter Osrick, Alfride, four servants, at the other door Arnold.

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.l: My lord, howe'er
Some of your servants are pleased to make themselves
Merry with a pretended knowledge of me,
I do presume your honour cannot know me.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.p: From one so false never came clearer truth.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: It is true, my honour
Cannot, nay, dares not know thee for a brother,
Although mine eyes through tears of grief and anger,
Discern the monster I have often called so.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Look that he come not near me;
Perfidious parricide, hast thou killed my father?
Destroyed the life that gave thee life? and now
Seekest by surprise to take mine too?

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Upon him all at once, hew him in pieces;
I'll bear you out in't; he has killed your lord.

sp.speaker: Off
sp.p: Villains, are they to be obeyed or I?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: My lord, your judgement is too rash upon them.
Fellows forbear, and forbear you my lord,
You shall not so heap blood upon your head;
I loved my lord your father, and do prize
His blood and memory, as becomes a servant
Of the best rank: and if at most and worst
My lord Anthynus here stand guilty of
His father's death, you must not be his judge,
Nor we his executioners.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Are you
Become my master, you old ruffian?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: No,
Your servant sir, but subject to the law;
The law that must determine this man's cause,
Not you, nor we, whatever he deserves.
And till he shall be censured by that law
We'll find a prison for him.

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.p: Will you but hear yet how you are mistaken?

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Pray heaven we be, as you may clear yourself;
That's all the harm we wish you; this must be
Your course my lord; would you heap blood upon you?

sp.speaker: Alsr.
sp.p: Let me but speak a word.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Away with 'em. Exeunt.
I could have liked the other shorter way
Much better; but my knaves will have it thus,
Yet not to wrong 'em, simple honesty
May be in such sometimes as well as me.

div.stage: Enter carpenter, Mason, smith, in devil's habits; two dark lanthorns, a pickaxe and a rope, with an engine fastened to a post, and a bunch of picklocks.

sp.speaker: Mason
sp.l: Prithee tread softly yet a little further,
And we are safe.

sp.speaker: Carpenter
sp.l: I never knew thieves so timorous as you are.
Can we expect a booty without boldness?
Besides, have we not shapes if we were spied,
Able to fright better believers than
My politic lord oth' house here.

sp.speaker: Carpenter
sp.l: Pray on I prithee; prayers become this coat,
Like swearing in a surplice; tush, they are all,
All the whole house asleep, and I heard nothing
As we passed through it, but usual sleepy sounds,
Puffing and blowing, snorting farting and such like.
Yes, I cry mercy, as we passed by the butlers chamber,
I heard his bed crackle shrewdly, and I doubt,
The dary-maid and he were jumbling of
A posset together. Come, now we are safely arrived at the
Fountain of our hopes, the well of comfort. Smith, lay
Down your picklocks, they have done well their office in our passage hither. Mason,
Advance your pickaxe, whilst the carpenter squares out
Our new work; now for the honour of artificers; here, here,
Here is the trap-door, the mouth of the rich mine, which
We'll make bold to open. And let men of our occupations
Learn the way that many grow rich by, and
Nobody knows how they come by their wealth. That
Is, when they make such concavities as these, for
Rich men to hide their treasure in, that they
Make also a privy way for themselves to come and
Take a share on't.

sp.speaker: Mason
sp.l: This covetous lord by this time has laid in
An unknown deal of wealth, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Smith
sp.p: But we'll not take away too much at once.

sp.speaker: Carpenter
sp.l: No, we'll but piddle; we'll not take above
A thousand pounds tonight .Opensso, I'll go down;
And when I shake the rope, than crane me up again; give me one of
The lanterns: so, so, so, let me down handsomely;
I'll warrant you money, the devil and all before day yet.

sp.speaker: Smith
sp.l: Nay, if we get off clear but with a thousand pound
Amongst us, it will serve for drinking
Money till we come for more.

sp.speaker: Mason
sp.l: This money will come luckily for a better purpose.
I have three bastards at nurse and a fourth in the paniers.
The rope stirs; pull lustily, this pull for a
Thousand pound.

sp.speaker: Smith
sp.l: I fear 'tis light gold, methinks he does not weigh
So heavy as he went down. Comrade, what hast thou
Brought? what ailest thou? canst not speak? I hope thou
Wert not frighted.

sp.speaker: 1. Outlaw
sp.p: O help! where am I? drawn from one hell into another? ha!

sp.speaker: Mason
sp.p: Come, leave your fooling, what money have you?

sp.speaker: 1. Outlaw
sp.l: Had I the price of kingdoms I'd give all
But for one bit of meat; but I have none.

sp.speaker: Smith
sp.l: 'Slid, he would cozen us; how do you look when you lie?
O me!

sp.speaker: Smith
sp.p: This is not he; it is a ghastly spirit.

sp.speaker: Mason
sp.l: Yes, but we have played the devils, till we have
Got a spirit betwixt us.

sp.speaker: 1. Outlaw
sp.p: If you be men, help me to food, a little food.

sp.speaker: Mason
sp.p: What art thou that canst look thus piepeck, crow-trod, or sparrow-blasted? ha!

sp.speaker: 1. Outl
sp.p: O, I am pined with hunger.

sp.speaker: Mas
sp.l: Here, stay thy stomach; there's a crust I brought
To stop the open mouth of the mastive, if he had flown at us.

sp.speaker: Smith
sp.p: There he is now I am sure.

sp.speaker: Carpenter
sp.p: Take his teeth out of me, I cannot tell you else.

div.stage: Pull up Carp. an Outl. hanging on him

sp.speaker: Mason
sp.p: O cannibal! wilt thou eat a carpenter?

sp.speaker: 2. Outlaw
sp.p: O meat, meat, if you be men.

sp.speaker: Mason
sp.l: No, we are devils; but here's another crust for thee
Whatever thou art; we have played the thieves to
Very good purpose.

sp.speaker: Carpenter
sp.l: He has gnawed a piece of my flank out with's teeth;
And missed very narrowly certain members of more moment,
they'd have gone down glib with him; now in the
Devil's name, what are ye?

sp.speaker: Smith
sp.p: Until their crusts be done they cannot tell us.

sp.speaker: Mason
sp.l: Come, I do suspect the subtlety of this cruel politic
Lord; would we were well out on's house. No noise my
Masters, and we'll bring you to meat enough; and then
We'll hear your story, and tell our own; a word more
Here, may cost all our lives.

sp.speaker: Smith.
sp.p: Take up your tools and lead the way.

sp.speaker: Mil.
sp.l: Had you the only tongue of all persuasion,
So much I prize my life, and honour more,
I would not miss this opportunity
For all that you could say.

sp.speaker: Carpenter
sp.l: No evil ones I'll warrant, they are so white;
Hark a little more.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Tonight he's troubled about Anthynus coming,
So that he will not think of lust or wantonness.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: That trouble keeps him waking; and I fear
Will rather spur him forwards then withhold him.

sp.speaker: Smith
sp.l: They talk methinks; but I cannot hear what
For shaking.

sp.speaker: Carpenter
sp.l: Take heed thou dost not jingle thy picklocks,; slid,
They'll ring up the house like a alarm bell.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Well, since you are so resolute, would we were out of the
House once, if we be taken, 'tis not the price of
A million of maidenheads, as the market goes, can save
Our lives.

sp.speaker: Carpenter
sp.l: Good, I have found what sprites they be. They
Must needs be the wenches that I suspected were in
The butlers chamber, and made the stiff standing bedstead that
I set up but last week, crack like a wicker chair.
Ah rogues! I heard ye.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.p: O me! we are undone and taken.

sp.speaker: Carpenter
sp.p: Peace, if you have a mind to scape out oth' house alive.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: Come nurse, my fear is over, if they be
Men, and bring us out oth' house,
They cannot be so dangerous as he I scaped.

sp.speaker: Carpenter
sp.p: Did he so put thee to't, my little bustlepate? what a stout blade's this butler?

sp.speaker: Carpenter
sp.l: Yes faith, and fear you nothing for all our devilish
Outsides; if we scape out of the house, you scape, and
If we fail, our necks are sure to hang by't; and so
On there afore once more in the name of darkness.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: If my attempt now fail, may my repulse
Strike lust for ever out of countenance. Ent. Offa, light and dagger.
It is decreed she sleeps with me or death

sp.speaker: 2. Outlaw
sp.p: Let us fall to and beat him.

sp.speaker: Carpenter
sp.l: As you can hope for meat again, or life,
Look big, and use no words; and so glide by.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: The night, the place, her fate, and my desire,
Do all conspire unto my wished advantage.
And so I come coy damosel. Hide the women under their habits, and so exeunt all but Offa.
Ha? how? why? where? who? or what can you or I be?
They are all gone, and I am tottering left
Upon an earthquake; gentle, holla, holla,
Set not too hard old Ops, thou'lt shake thy rider,
Through thy chinky wrinkles into limbo.
I shall sink piecemeal if thou trot so hard.
So, so, so, holla, holla, gentle earth.
Open not here, not near that part of thee
That has but now disgorged those famished ghosts,
That with the furies would have beckoned me
Along to hell with 'em; so, let me down,
I must not follow yet, but sleep and think upon't.
I will come time enough you need not fear.
But first creep back to bed, as nothing were.

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.l: You have told me wonders, which have pierced my soul
With horror and amazement; yet I must confess,
In all that I am like to suffer, heaven is just,
Whilst wrath my wilfulness has pulled upon me;
Yet pardon, since thou gavest me that affection
That wandered with me in this oblique course,
This uncouth way, with which I have not strayed
Further than love might lead an humane frailty.

sp.speaker: Eth.
sp.l: You do consider well, my lord, and we
Beseech you strive to countercheck these crosses
Still with your kingly reason.

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.l: Yes, and fall upon our present business; there you find me
Out of a spacious kingdom of mine own,
Shut in a narrow prison; whilst the brother
Of her, whose love I came to seek, has married
The Queen I might have had; before I have seen
His sister; there was a quick expedition.

sp.speaker: Eth.
sp.l: My lord, for that before you left the court
In your supposed distraction; the o'erbusy lords
Eaufride and Theodwald, out of strong conceit
The sight of her would cure you, feigned your letters
Which fetched the Queen; then banished us the court,
Before we could take notice; we had been
Strong traitors else to let that match go forwards.
Nor heard we of it until now the post
That brings the news oth' Kings and Queen's approach
Arrived here in the city.

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.p: All think him then their King still?

sp.speaker: Eth.
sp.l: Yes, yes, and though he told us who he was;
The overwise lords imputed that to his madness.

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.l: It seems he was not so mad, but he could take
The Queen into my bed.

sp.speaker: Eth.
sp.l: Where she liked him so well
That she now brings him home unto her own.
Still thinking him your person.

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.l: Whilst I lie here for his,
Accused of parricide; but I will not
Reveal myself till trial. Ent. Mildred
Now all my sufferings are turned into delightful recreations.
Fairest of virgin's welcome; marvel not
That at first sight I knew you, when my heart
Wears the impression of your portraiture;
And all my intellectual faculties
Bow to no other object but your beauty.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: O sir, lay by this high dissimulation;
For though I find you now are not my brother.

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.l: Lo ye, she knows I am not Anthynus.
Her virtue like the sun will clear the mist
Of error we were lost in.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: Not Anthynus?
Yes, the bright sun discovers not a truth
More evident than that you are Anthynus
Nor ever shined on man I loved so well,
Or hoped to marry, since you are not my brother.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: Indeed I came
To tell you so, and could you clear your hand
Of the foul stain of blood you are accused of,
Were I sole monarchess of all this island,
I'd kneel to beg a bride's place in your bed.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: Nay, mark me further;
If you clear not yourself, I'll not outlive you,
To call to mind the man that I so loved
Butchered his father; though he was not mine,
I loved him as a father; o good heaven!
How good? how reverend a man was he?

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.l: Weep not, but hear me; or hear me though you weep;
I am not Anthynus.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: I may say as well,
I do not love you.

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.l: I never had an hand
In blood of any man.

sp.speaker: Edel.
sp.l: I saw one i'th next room
Drinking and singing catches with some prisoners.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Withhold your hands, Anthynus now again,
Fair lady, is your brother.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.p: Why did you mock me then?

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: To save you from your brother Offa's lust,
I feigned that you were not his sister; that
In hope to marry you, he might forbear
His devilish purpose.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: Now I am lost for ever,
In being the daughter of a murdered father,
And made uncapable of you in marriage.

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.p: Yet hear me, and be comforted.

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.p: I do not know that name.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: Go to, go to; nor you do not remember
How I behaved myself upon the eating of spurging
Comfects, that your brother Offa gave me,
And laid the fault on you; pray Jove, I say, this murder
Be no more his fault than yours.

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.l: Hark, the wide world abroad is filled with joy,
And must we only be shut from it? now.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: You are called unto your trial.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: Those that are bribe-free I dare warrant 'em.
It may perhaps go somewhat the harder with you;
For nothing but white innocence can quit you,
Pray heaven you have't about you; even the King
And Queen, the Queen and King I should have said,
For she's our sovereign, 'tis her law must do it.

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.p: What King do you mean then?

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.p: Yes, I know him as well as he knows himself.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Take heed sir what you say.

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.l: I fear him not,
But am as good as he; now carry me for something.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.p: Peace, he did not say so.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: 'Slid, he's as mad as his brother Offa.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: O quite besides himself, and talks the strangeliest
Of his father's murder, your running away
And the desire he has to hang his brother here;
And than he is haunted with sprites too, they say;
You will know all anon; will you go my lord?

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.p: Yes, will you be so kind as to see my trial?

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.p: Indeed I must not leave you.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.l: 'Tis a kind part indeed, and may become
A sister; like the wife that would not leave
Her husband till she saw him totter.
Set the best foot forward, and the best face
You can, my lord, upon the business. Exeunt.
Hoboys.

div.stage: Enter Theodwald and Eaufride, Kelrick and Elkwin, Theodrick, Anthynus and Bertha.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Long live King Osrick and Queen Bertha.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: I join with ye in your wishes for the Queen;
And wish well to King Osrick as a stranger.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: But will no longer personate him;
For now be it known to you that I am no Osrick;
But he that warns you call me so no more.

sp.speaker: Theodw.
sp.p: He's madder now than e'er he was.

sp.speaker: Eauf.
sp.l: I am at my wits end too; if marriage
Will not tame him, I know not what to say to't.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: I have told you truth, and your fair grace can witness
How violently I was thrown upon the fortune,
I thank those provident lords, against my vow.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: I take it as the providence of heaven;
And from the son of that most injured father,
Whom now in my joys strength I could shed tears for.
I yield you are my head, and I your handmaid.

div.stage: She sets him down, and kneels; he takes her up.

sp.speaker: Eauf.
sp.l: So, so, a few night's trial has got her liking
For ever fast enough; what notable old coxcombs
Have we been made? nay, made ourselves indeed.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Now further know, my lords, I am Anthynus,
The son of that old honest lord, 'gainst whom
Your sulphurous malice kindled the Queen's anger.

sp.speaker: Elkw.
sp.p: Who'll have an head now for an half penny?

sp.speaker: Kelr ▪
sp.p: And for tother two tokens mine into the bargain.

div.stage: Enter keeper, with Osrick, Ethelswick, Edith, Alfride, Edelred, guard.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Make way there for the prisoner.

sp.speaker: Theodw.
sp.p: Ay, this is our King indeed.

sp.speaker: Theodr.
sp.p: O let me wash your feet sir with my tears.

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.l: Thy trespass is thine honour my Theodrick ▪
And I must thank your care my lords, as it deserves,
Your overreaching care to give my dignity
As much as in you lay unto another.
And for your letters counterfeit in my name,
By which the Queen is mocked into a marriage.

sp.speaker: Theodw.
sp.p: That was your policy, your wit, my lord.

sp.speaker: Eauf.
sp.l: A shame on't. would I were hanged, that I
Might hear no more on't.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: Fair sir, the Queen is pleased, and hopes you are
In her that's so much fairer in your thoughts.

sp.speaker: Osr
sp.l: Yes, my noble brother,
She stands in fortune equal with yourself,
In being mine.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: But not great sir, until
You are acquitted of my father's murder.

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.l: I am clear of that, as I am not Anthynus.
Anthynus is accused, not Osrick sir,
Your father is required at your hands.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: But his accuser reads another lesson
Now madam.

div.stage: Offa brought bound in a chair.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Whither do you hurry me?
If I must answer't, give me yet some time,
To make provision of befitting presents,
To supply the hard hands of my stern judges,
Into a tender feeling of my cause:
I know what Aeacus loves, what mines likes,
And what will make grave Radamanthus run.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Yes, and speaks heinous things
Against himself, both of my lords murder,
And an intended rare against his sister.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.l: Hark, how the devil lies;
I have no sister.

sp.speaker: Ed.
sp.l: How he's possessed
Of that strange error; I must satisfy you?
That was merely feigned by me to save her honour
from his outrageous lust.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: But here comes that
Clears all at once.
Welcome my honoured lords.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: A boon, a boon, my gracious liege.

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.p: You are my father in your daughters right.

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.p: But see Anthynus at a greater height.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: And my father noble sir.
Your pardon, and for ever welcome.

sp.speaker: Seg.
sp.p: If this were real now, and not a dream!

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.l: Come, leave your fooling, hear a wise man speak:
Great King according unto thy behest
With knights adventurers I went in quest,
Through the woods and forests wild
To scour the dens of outlaws vild;
Whence these old men, this knave I bring
Together with this starveling;
Whom I present not dead, but quick
Unto thy grace King Osrick.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.l: Look this way fool,
This is King Osrick man.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.l: Whoop, hold a little, best let me be everybody's fool
Round about the house.
But amongst you all, let me not lose reward;
I must not fool for naught; the times are hard.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: I owe thee a just reward, for I proclaimed
To him that brought this man alive or dead
A thousand crowns; but since thou art so fortunate
To bring him home alive and well recovered
Out of such danger —

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: I shall have nothing shall I?

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: I'll double thy reward, give thee two thousand crows.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.l: It is enough in conscience; who bids more?
For till you are out-bidden, I'll be your fool.
But can you tell whose favourite you are then?

sp.speaker: Theodr.
sp.p: Where I was first, I'll ever wish to be.

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.l: And I'll be thine Theodrick; for thou in this
Hast above favour shown me unto bliss.

sp.speaker: Seg.
sp.l: I have performed your majesty's command,
Though not in sending, yet in bringing home
My banished friend, lord Alberto, the preserver
Of my now happy life.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.p: It shall be to his honour; welcome Alberto.

sp.speaker: Outlaw
sp.p: O what an heavenly smell of meat is here!

sp.speaker: Seg.
sp.l: All the unhappiness I now can see
Is but an argument of tears for thee,
In whom I'm justly punished.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Take him hence
From my grieved father's sight.

sp.speaker: Seg.
sp.l: And pray let care
Be had for his recovery; his senses may
Bring a new soul into him, for which I pray.

sp.speaker: Arn.
sp.p: Yes, yes, my lord, all's well.

sp.speaker: Off.
sp.p: I knew my bribes would do it.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.l: I'll off with him, for 'tis unknown to you
What good a fool may on a mad man do.

sp.speaker: Seg.
sp.l: This sword was evidence enough against him;
But here's one of the outlaws that confessed it;
for whom, since he is penitent, I beg pardon.

sp.speaker: Mild.
sp.l: The other two his fellows are both extant:
For whom together with three thievish workmen
That were strong instruments in my delivery,
Let me beg mercy.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: I have heard of them that robbed my brother's jewelhouse.
'Tis a day of grace,
And we are taught by heavens abundant mercy
Shown upon us beyond our expectation,
To imitate that goodness.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: I forgive
All on my part.

sp.speaker: Bert.
sp.l: And now right royal sir, let me entreat
For former love, to make our last complete,
You will be pleased a month with us to stay
In triumphs to commemorate this day.

sp.speaker: Osr.
sp.l: Next to my sum of happiness my bride,
I should have sought that honour, royal sister.

sp.speaker: Anth.
sp.l: Thus through tempestuous sighs and showers of tears
Joy at the last more cheerfully appears.

div.closer: Ric. Bromedeus dedit his quoque finem.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
